text: HTML Emails are such a pain sometimes :sweat:
Client is going to love how it exceeds 102kb making the Gmail App cut the email short and showing 'view entire message'
on the upside, if you’re really good at HTML emails it’s really good job security

I quite literally just got an email from a client about an email template I’ve never touched before saying “Having this issue with images in outlook” I knew immediately what the problem was and had it fixed in under 5 minutes. It was a specific quirk to Outlook.

I have done too much HTML email work for my own good though.
On that note, would you say Litmus is the go to source for figuring out different email quirks or do you have other favorite resources?

Litmus is by far one of the best sources of information on all email quirks. Good source of inspiration too. Campaign Monitor is another good source, they made this invaluable site: <https://www.campaignmonitor.com/css/>

I have a lot of resources for HTML emails though over-all. I’d feel bad though if I gave em all away over slack as we just landed a project teaching another developer how to do HTML emails for their company, and these are all resources I gave them.

Litmus though is probably the best advice I could give anyone. Their service may be pricey, but the amount of hours it saves you is worth every single penny.
Jon, no worries, business is business. Thanks anyway!

HubSpot uses Litmus for their email previews, but it’s nothing in comparison to using actual litmus - they have amazing tools - like the ability to live preview your emails in other email clients - then when you find a problem, you can inspect inside the email client, and live edit the html and css of the email like you would a browser, to troubleshoot. It’s flipping amazing

on top of that you can give them your html code and instantly it will show you a giant list of every css property or html issue that will cause a problem in an email client and which client, with quick references for a lot of those things on how to add support for that client
jeepers cats, that sounds amazing. Maybe one day when we have the money...
well my philosophy on it is if your client is willing to pay you x for x hours substitute 1 of your hours to pay for litmus, you can always cancel at the end of the month when you’re done using it.
true true, I'll try phrasing it that way and see what happens
odds are paying for it, really means subtracting potentially several hours of mind numbing troubleshooting and going down rabbit holes
And cursing Microsoft for using the Microsoft word rendering engine for half the versions of Outlook instead of Internet Explorer or Edge’s
